channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: Junior Perl Developer who needs a career boost?
item.description: Taking the journey from Junior to Senior â€“ and building a strong work history â€“ is a lot more fun in the right job

item.title: Perl mentor needed for large and growing team - train the next generation of Perl developers in London
item.description: Do you have some great Perl war stories? Can you help guide and grow the experience of junior Perl developers? Never get tired of explaining what use utf8; doesnâ€™t do?

item.title: Sometimes, it's about the people - Perl developer in West London
item.description: The project is challenging, the team is great and the company is both successful and growing. The best possible mix to ensure you enjoy your time at work

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

item.title: On Raku
item.description: What do you need to do if you really want to use the Raku name instead of Perl 6 and how to get over this extra nickname. Comments here and here

item.title: Announce: Raku Perl 6 'Diwali' 6.d Language Specification Release
item.description: It is a huge step for the deveopment of Perl 6, but for most of us it is 'just' a document. Once we'll have the Rakudo compile that will be the bigger issue. Still you might want to read ahead on what will be in this new version that will be released within a few weeks.

item.title: Maintaining Perl 5 (Tony Cook): October 2018 Grant Report
Maintaining the Perl 5 Core (Dave Mitchell): Grant Report for September and October 2018
Rakudo Perl 6 performance analysis tooling - Grant Report #5
meta::hack is back!
item.description: Working on Meta::CPAN while being co-located.

item.title: Larry Wall Announces Alternative Name 'Raku' for Perl 6
item.description: This is not the annuncement by Larry Wall. Here Sue tells us a bit about the storm that followed the 'announcement'.

item.title: Moose Loose Ends
item.description: The Loose end series in the Moose series. This is episode one, but there are already 8 episodes.

item.title: Quo vadis, Perl?
item.description: Claudio describes several possible scenarios regarding the future of Perl 5 and Perl 6.

item.title: Rakudo Star Release 2018.10
item.description: A new release of Rakudo. Already using the name Raku, but still based on the previous spec.

item.title: (Test) Automation - CI - CD - DevOps
item.description: As you might know my day-job is to help teams improve their development process by introducing Test Automation, CI/CD and other DevOps practices. Mostly I work with local customers, but I have started to work with a remote client and I wish to expand this. So if you feel your organization could get some boost in that area, get in touch with me.

item.description: StickerYou.com is your one-stop shop to make your business stick. You can create custom stickers, labels, decals, magnets, and more in any size, shape, and order quantity. If youâ€™re printing your own custom stickers for your staff or to hand out at events, we have you covered. Start designing today with StickerYouâ€™s world-leading sticker maker. Use code PERL10 at checkout for a 10% discount.

item.title: #381 - What is the name of my Perl? Raku? Rakudo? Perl? Perl 5? Perl 6?
item.description:
Hi there,

this was a confusing week for me and I am trying to clarify things for myself. Maybe it will help you too. Or confuse you even more. Pick whichever fits you!

Raku is a type of Japanese pottery and also the nickname of an (old/new) programming language once people referred to as 'the future of Perl' or the 'demise of Perl'. It can be found at Raku.do. (Though I would think it should be Raku.does correctly. Unless, of course, if Raku is plural.)

Diwali is the Hindu festival of lights and also the code name of the most recent definition of a programming language. This is what got released this week, but it is not something you can 'run'. It is 'just' a sepcification.

Rakudo the name of the implementation of a programming language. (compiler/interpreter). You can download and install it from here. The most recent version is from yesterday, but it is still based on the spec that was around before the Diwali spec was released.

Rakudo Star is a 'distribution' or 'packaging' of the Rakudo compiler/interpreter with documentation and a bunch of additional code that make it more useful. This is also pre-Diwali, but eventually, hopefully, definitely (etc.) a new version will be released soon. (This is what you need to try things out.)

Perl 6 a sister if Perl 5 where the family name is Perl and the given names are 5 and 6. Extra points for writing in the 'Hungarian order' - family name first.

So if I wanted to avoid futher confusion, I'd just stick to Rakudo Perl 6 for now.

I hope some of these links will help you avoid doing your job for 2 hours.

Enjoy your week
